item.title: [KAFKA-3409] Mirror maker hangs indefinitely due to commit
item.description:
Mirror maker hangs indefinitely upon receiving CommitFailedException. I believe this is due to CommitFailedException not caught by mirror maker and mirror maker has no way to recover from it.

A better approach will be catching the exception and rejoin the group. Here is the stack trace

comments.comment:
This can happen if consumer rebalance is in progress. Offsets must have already been committed during onPartitionsRevoked event handling. Would it be fair to simply ignore this exception? Something like this, https://github.com/SinghAsDev/kafka/commit/e411607b878df5becd9cead783768eede6e1fb9d

becket_qin, hachikuji thoughts?

This can also happen when producer is slow and buffer memory is full which results in blocking consumer from polling therefore session times out. Next time consumer calls commit or poll it has been kicked out of the group. In this case it has no chance to call commit in onPartitionsRevoked and the consumed offset is lost which subsequently introduces message duplication.

singhashish Yes, I think we should swallow it. Even a true consumer offset commit failure in MM is not a disaster and we probably should just continue.

One thing to notice is that In the old consumer, we have an offset commit max retries default to 5. New consumer does not have this configuration. Although user can retry by themselves, it does not look a good user experience. I am not sure if this has been discussed before in the new consumer design. hachikuji any ideas?

xiaotao183 Yes, there are a few scenarios in which offset commit might fail. But duplicates is not avoidable when a member died / stalled unless we commit offset for each message, which would be super inefficient.

In the case of CommitFailedException, there's really no way to retry. This exception is only raised when the consumer has fallen out of the group. In that case, the partitions it's trying to commit offsets for has already been assigned to another consumer in the group. We could let commitSync() complete a rebalance and then try again if the consumer happens to get assigned the same partitions, but whichever consumer had temporarily owned those partitions may have already committed new offsets. So it seems like all we can do is raise the exception.

That makes sense.

So it seems that if users see CommitFailedException, there are two possibilities:
1) the consumer hasn't been polling for quite a while so it has been kicked out of the group.
2) user happened to call commit offset while the consumer is going through the rebalance and has passed the PreparingRebalance stage.

In (1) user should expect the exception, because the issue was due to the user did not call poll() frequent enough.
I am not sure if 2) is a possible scenario in a single threaded model. That might still be possible. After a user calls poll(), the left over state could be something like AwaitingSync. And if user call commitSync() at that point, it will fail. So does it mean even if a consumer is still in the group, it might still see CommitFailedException as long as it is trying to commit offset during a rebalance?

Do you think we should document some suggestions for user to correctly handle this exception? If both case are possible, I am wondering if we should throw the RebalanceInProgressException instead of CommitFailedException to user in case (2). Otherwise users might think they are not polling frequent enough which might not be the case.

I think the only way (2) could happen at the moment is if the user calls wakeup() and aborts a rebalance that was in progress. As long as you don't try to commit offsets after a wakeup, it shouldn't happen.

I tried to improve the exception message in KAFKA-3318 to give the user some better advice. We could mention something about the case above if you think it will help (it might just confuse though since it's a little subtle). If we ever figure out how to make poll() non-blocking on rebalance, then we'll have to address it more directly.

I have an something similar exception, running with two MirrorMaker (These have their own consumer group). Both Cluster runs 0.9.1.
Both stops working on the same time and freeze. Why does the mirrormaker not stop completeley, process is still running so is assume its still working what it does not.
Correct behavior should be stop process and give feedback to the system that the service is not running anymore or retry to connect consumer.
